subSections.title: Glyph origin
Etymology
subSections.text:
From {{inh|zh|sit-pro|*m-bru(ŋ/k)||dragon; thunder}}. Cognate with {{cog|bo|འབྲུག||dragon; thunder}}. The STEDT database also lists {{och-l|隆|thunder; sound of thunder}} and {{och-l|雹|hail}} as cognates. Also compare {{och-l|靐|sound of thunder}} and {{och-l|霹靂|thunder}}.

This word is found in many languages of the region. Compare {{cog|hmx-pro|*-roŋ||dragon}} ({{cog|mww|zaj}}), {{cog|mkh-vie-pro|*-roːŋ||dragon}} ({{cog|vi|rồng}}), {{cog|vi|thuồng luồng|'''thuồng''' luồng|serpent-like monster}}, {{cog|km|រោង||year of the dragon}}, {{cog|th|มะโรง||dragon; year of the dragon}}, {{cog|lo|ມະໂລງ||year of the dragon}}, perhaps also {{cog|otk|*-lan|''*-lan''|suffix denoting a wild, predatory animal}} ({{cog|tr|aslan||lion}}, {{m|tr|kaplan||tiger}}, {{m|tr|yılan||snake}}).

subSections.title: Usage notes
subSections.text:
* [[kyūjitai|Kyūjitai]]; simplified into {{m|ja|竜}} as isolated shinjitai kanji, but used in Jōyō characters {{m|ja|襲}} and {{m|ja|籠}} (latter Jōyō as of 2010).
** Although it is officially simplified into {{m|ja|竜}}, {{m|ja||龍}} is often used instead for certain words for its aesthetics (such as in literary contexts or for spelling words borrowed from Chinese). For example, {{m|ja|烏龍茶}} is rarely spelled as {{m|ja|烏竜茶}}.

Compounds
subSections.text:
* {{l|ko|청룡}}(靑龍) Green [[dragon]]
* {{l|ko|용문}}(龍門) dragon gate (folk tale : If snake passes this gate, it becomes a dragon)
* {{l|ko|용왕}}(龍王) the Dragon King
* {{l|ko|용산}}(龍山) [[Yongsan]] [[city]]
* {{l|ko|용인}}(龍仁) [[Yongin]] [[city]]
* {{l|ko|용수철}}(龍鬚鐵) [[spring]]
* {{l|ko|등용문}}(登龍門) [[gateway]]
* {{l|ko|용두사미}}(龍頭蛇尾) [[anticlimax]], dragon head and snake tail
* {{l|ko|공룡}}(恐龍) [[dinosaur]]

subSections.title: Etymology
subSections.text: Coblin, reconstructing the Pai-lang pronunciation as *''gljung'', suggests that it derives from {{der|tbq-plg|sit-pro|*kl(j)u(ŋ/k)||river, gorge}} and retains its consonant cluster, which was lost in Proto-Lolo-Burmese. Compare {{cog|bo|ལྗོངས}}, {{cog|zh|-}} {{och-l|谷|id=2}}.

subSections.title: Noun
subSections.text:
{{head|tbq-plg|noun|tr=*gljung}}

# [[gorge]]

* Christopher I. Beckwith, "The Pai-lang songs: The earliest texts in a Tibeto-Burman language and their Late Old Chinese transcriptions" (2008), in ''Medieval Tibeto-Burman Languages III''
